elementSpec.desc: summarizes the way in which hyphenation in a source text has been treated in an encoded version of it.

attDef.desc: indicates the character(s) used to encode hyphens that did not occur at end-of-line in the source
attDef.valDesc: A list of one or more characters, represented either by the character itself (which, of course, may be represented as an XML numeric character reference) or by listing its 4-digit hexidecimal Unicode codepoint preceded by U+.

remarks.p:
By far the most common character used for this is U+002D, which is next to 0 on a typical QWERTY keyboard. The most appropriate character, however, is U+2010. Many other possibilities exist, including:
codepoint character name
U+2010 ‐ HYPHEN
U+2011 ‑ NON-BREAKING HYPHEN
U+002D - HYPHEN-MINUS
U+2043 ⁃ HYPHEN BULLET
U+FF0D － FULLWIDTH HYPHEN-MINUS
U+FE63 ﹣ SMALL HYPHEN-MINUS
U+058A ֊ ARMENIAN HYPHEN
U+1400 ᐀ CANADIAN SYLLABICS HYPHEN
U+30A0 ゠ KATAKANA-HIRAGANA DOUBLE HYPHEN
U+2E17 ⸗ DOUBLE OBLIQUE HYPHEN
U+2E1A ⸚ HYPHEN WITH DIAERESIS
U+00AD ­ SOFT HYPHEN
U+1806 ᠆ MONGOLIAN TODO SOFT HYPHEN
U+2027 ‧ HYPHENATION POINT

attDef.desc: indicates the character(s) used to encode hyphens that occured at end-of-line, or between lines, in the source

valItem.desc: The same character used to indicate an intraline hyphen is used to indicate an interline hyphen; no attempt has been made to differentiate soft from hard hyphens. This is often used for encoding generated from OCR.

valItem.gloss: same as for intraline, hard hyphens only
valItem.desc: Hard interline hyphens have been encoded using the same character as used to indicate an intraline hyphen. Soft hyphens have not been recorded at all, and words which were broken across a line break have been joined. If line breaks are encoded this one has either been moved or dropped as to not interupt the word.

Hard interline hyphens have been encoded using the same character as for intraline hyphens. Soft interline hyphen characters have not been encoded, but the fact that the line break interupts a word has been encoded using the break attribute of the element that encodes the intervening break (typically a cb, lb, or pb).

End-of-line hyphens have been encoded using the same character as for intraline hyphens. In addition, when a word is interupted by a break (whether or not a hyphen was present), this has been encoded using the break attribute of the element that encodes the intervening break (typically a cb, lb, or pb).
